awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Computational and Geometric aspects of Lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on lattice-based cryptography, an area born in the late 1990s, and that has since grown tremendously. Lattices are mathematical objects defined as the the set of all integer combinations of some n linearly independent vectors in n-dimensional Euclidean space. For instance, the set of all integer points in n-dimensional Euclidean space forms a lattice. For n=2, this is the set of all points in the familiar Cartesian plane with integer coordinates. Lattices have attracted the attention of mathematicians for over two centuries, and have an impressive number of applications in mathematics and computer science, from number theory and Diophantine approximation to complexity theory and cryptography. Lattice-based cryptography is unique in that it is believed to be secure against attacks using quantum computers, a feature not shared by any of the traditional cryptographic schemes such as RSA (named for its inventors' initials). Moreover, recent work has shown that lattice-based cryptography is practical, and that it is amazingly versatile, leading to a remarkable number of applications such as fully homomorphic encryption, which allows computation on encrypted data.

The main goal of the project is establishing even stronger foundations for lattice-based cryptography by finding tighter hardness reductions and understanding the mysterious role quantum computing plays in it. The project also includes the development of new classical and quantum algorithms for lattice problems, as well as an investigation into some of the geometrical properties of lattices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on mathematical objects known as lattices, and their behavior in high dimensions (contrary to their low dimensional properties appearing, e.g., in crystallography). These objects form the basis for a modern kind of cryptography known as ``post-quantum cryptography'' (or cryptography secure against quantum computers), which is currently being standardized by NIST based partly on work of the PI.

The project supported two PhD students, and one MS student. Together with the PI, they made progress on several central open questions in the field. The results were published in top conferences and journals in the area.

Specifically, in work with Joan Bruna and supported students Min Jae Song and Yi Tang, we provided strong evidence that a natural question in machine learning (learning mixtures of Gaussians) is computationally hard. The proof uses a connection with lattices and quantum computation. This result answers several recent open questions in the machine learning literature. It can also be seen as a new variant of Learning with Errors (LWE) which might have its own applications. This result appeared in the main theoretical computer science conference, STOC 2021.

Another research outcome was achieved in joint work with Barak Weiss and Or Ordentlich. Here we explored properties of random lattices. In particular, we were interested in their covering radius, which is defined as the maximum distance of a point in space from the lattice (e.g., for the two-dimensional integer lattice that distance is 1/√2). We were able to show that random lattices have an exceptionally low covering radius. The result improves on classical work of Rogers from over half a century ago, who was also interested in showing good covering lattices, but was only able to provide weaker bounds, and did not analyze random lattices. Interestingly, the proof relies crucially on recent results on the so-called Kakeya problem due to Dvir and others, which we strengthen in the course of our proof. This result appears in the Journal of the AMS.

Together with Golovnev, Posobin, and Weinstein, we proved a polynomial lower bound for an explicit range counting problem against linear storage arithmetic data structures in the group model. Our result addresses a fundamental challenge in computational geometry. Our construction and analysis are based on a combination of techniques in Diophantine approximation, pseudorandomness, and compressed sensing—in particular, on the existence and partial derandomization of optimal binary compressed sensing matrices in the polynomial sparsity regime. The result appeared in the main theoretical computer science conference, FOCS 2020, and was invited to the SIAM J. on Computation special issue dedicated to the top ~10% of papers in the conference.

The PI was invited to give a talk and contribute a paper to the 2022 International Congress of Mathematicians. He will present his NSF-supported work on the reverse Minkowski theorem.
